column1: Hurricane Sandy (unofficially referred to as Superstorm Sandy) was the deadliest and most destructive
column2: as well as the strongest hurricane of the 2012 Atlantic hurricane season. The storm inflicted nearly $70 billion (2012 USD) in damage and killed 233 people across eight countries from the Caribbean to Canada. The eighteenth named storm
column3: tenth hurricane
column4: and second major hurricane of the year
column5: Sandy was a Category 3 storm at its peak intensity when it made landfall in Cuba. While it was a Category 2 hurricane off the coast of the Northeastern United States
column6: the storm became the largest Atlantic hurricane on record (as measured by diameter
column7: with tropical-storm-force winds spanning 1
column8: 150 miles (1
column9: 850 km)).Sandy developed from a tropical wave in the western Caribbean Sea on October 22
column10: quickly strengthened
column11: and was upgraded to Tropical Storm Sandy six hours later. Sandy moved slowly northward toward the Greater Antilles and gradually intensified. On October 24
column12: Sandy became a hurricane
column13: made landfall near Kingston
column15: re-emerged a few hours later into the Caribbean Sea and strengthened into a Category 2 hurricane. On October 25

column17: then weakened to a Category 1 hurricane. Early on October 26
column18: Sandy moved through the Bahamas. On October 27
column19: Sandy briefly weakened to a tropical storm and then restrengthened to a Category 1 hurricane. Early on October 29
column20: Sandy curved west-northwest (the "left turn" or "left hook") and then moved ashore near Brigantine
column22: just to the northeast of Atlantic City
column23: as a post-tropical cyclone with hurricane-force winds. Sandy continued drifting inland for another few days while gradually weakening
column24: until it was absorbed by another approaching extratropical storm on November 2.In Jamaica
column25: winds left 70% of residents without electricity
column28: and caused about $100 million (2012 USD) in damage. Sandy's outer bands brought flooding to Haiti
column32: 000 homeless; the hurricane also caused two deaths in the Dominican Republic. In Puerto Rico

column38: and causing $2 billion (2012 USD) in damage. Sandy caused two deaths and an estimated $700 million (2012 USD) in damage in The Bahamas.

column2: Hurricane Sandy affected 24 states
column3: including the entire eastern seaboard from Florida to Maine and west across the Appalachian Mountains to Michigan and Wisconsin
column4: with particularly severe damage in New Jersey and New York. Its storm surge hit New York City on October 29
column5: flooding streets
column6: tunnels and subway lines and cutting power in and around the city. Damage in the United States amounted to $65 billion (2012 USD). In Canada
column7: two were killed in Ontario
column8: and the storm caused an estimated $100 million (2012 CAD) in damage throughout Ontario and Quebec.

column1: Hurricane Sandy began as a low pressure system which developed sufficient organized convection to be classified as Tropical Depression Eighteen on October 22 south of Kingston
column2: Jamaica. It moved slowly at first due to a ridge to the north. Low wind shear and warm waters allowed for strengthening
column3: and the system was named Tropical Storm Sandy late on October 22. Early on October 24
column4: an eye began developing
column5: and it was moving steadily northward due to an approaching trough. Later that day
column6: the National Hurricane Center (NHC) upgraded Sandy to hurricane status about 65 mi (105 km) south of Kingston
column7: Jamaica. At about 1900 UTC that day
column8: Sandy made landfall near Kingston with winds of about 85 mph (140 km/h). Just offshore Cuba
column9: Sandy rapidly intensified to a Category 3 hurricane
column10: with sustained winds at 115 mph (185 km/h) and a minimum central pressure of 954 millibars (28.2 inHg)
column11: and at that intensity
column12: Sandy made landfall just west of Santiago de Cuba at 0525 UTC on October 25. Operationally
column13: Sandy was assessed to have peaked as a high-end Category 2 hurricane
column14: with maximum sustained winds of 110 mph (175 km/h).

column2: the structure of the storm became disorganized
column3: and it turned to the north-northwest over the Bahamas. By October 27
column4: Sandy was no longer fully tropical
column5: as evidenced by the development of frontal structures in the outer circulation. Despite strong shear
column6: Sandy maintained its convection due to influence from an approaching trough; the same that turned the hurricane to the northeast. After briefly weakening to a tropical storm
column7: Sandy re-intensified into a Category 1 hurricane
column8: and on October 28
column9: an eye began redeveloping. The storm moved around an upper-level low over the eastern United States and also to the southwest of a ridge over Atlantic Canada
column10: turning it to the northwest.

column1: Sandy briefly re-intensified to Category 2 intensity on the morning of October 29
column2: around which time it had become an extremely large hurricane
column3: with a record gale-force wind diameter of over 1
column4: 150 miles (1
column6: and an unusually low central barometric pressure of 940 mbar
column7: possibly due to the very large size of the system. This pressure set records for many cities across the Northeastern United States for the lowest pressures ever observed. The convection diminished while the hurricane accelerated toward the New Jersey coast
column8: and the cyclone was no longer tropical by 2100 UTC on October 29. About 2½ hours later
column9: Sandy made landfall near Brigantine
column10: New Jersey
column11: with sustained winds of 80 mph (130 km/h). During the next four days
column12: Sandy's remnants drifted northward and then northeastward over Ontario
column13: before merging with another low pressure area over Eastern Canada on November 2.

column3: the path of Hurricane Sandy was correctly predicted by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) headquartered in Reading
column4: England nearly eight days in advance of its striking the American East Coast. The computer model noted that the storm would turn west towards land and strike the New York/New Jersey region on October 29
column5: rather than turn east and head out to the open Atlantic as most hurricanes in this position do. By October 27
column6: four days after the ECMWF made its prediction
column7: the National Weather Service and National Hurricane Center confirmed the path of the hurricane predicted by the European model. The National Weather Service was criticized for not employing its higher-resolution forecast models the way that its European counterpart did. A hardware and software upgrade completed at the end of 2013 enabled the weather service to make predictions more accurate and farther in advance than the technology in 2012 had allowed.

column1: According to NCAR senior climatologist Kevin E. Trenberth
column2: "The answer to the oft-asked question of whether an event is caused by climate change is that it is the wrong question. All weather events are affected by climate change because the environment in which they occur is warmer and moister than it used to be." Although NOAA meteorologist Martin Hoerling attributes Sandy to "little more than the coincidental alignment of a tropical storm with an extratropical storm"
column3: Trenberth does agree that the storm was caused by "natural variability" but adds that it was "enhanced by global warming". One factor contributing to the storm's strength was abnormally warm sea surface temperatures offshore the East Coast of the United States—more than 3 °C (5 °F) above normal
column4: to which global warming had contributed 0.6 °C (1 °F). As the temperature of the atmosphere increases
column5: the capacity to hold water increases
column6: leading to stronger storms and higher rainfall amounts.As they move north
column7: Atlantic hurricanes typically are forced east and out to sea by the Prevailing Westerlies.  In Sandy's case
column8: this typical pattern was blocked by a ridge of high pressure over Greenland resulting in a negative North Atlantic Oscillation
column9: forming a kink in the jet stream
column10: causing it to double back on itself off the East Coast.  Sandy was caught up in this northwesterly flow.  The blocking pattern over Greenland also stalled an Arctic front which combined with the cyclone. Mark Fischetti of Scientific American said that the jet stream's unusual shape was caused by the melting of Arctic ice. Trenberth said that while a negative North Atlantic Oscillation and a blocking anticyclone were in place
column11: the null hypothesis remained that this was just the natural variability of weather. Sea level at New York and along the New Jersey coast has increased by nearly a foot (300 mm) over the last hundred years
column12: which contributed to the storm surge. Harvard geologist Daniel P. Schrag calls Hurricane Sandy's 13-foot (4 m) storm surge an example of what will
column13: by mid-century
column14: be the "new norm on the Eastern seaboard".

column1: Much of the East Coast of the United States
column2: in Mid-Atlantic and New England regions
column3: had a good chance of receiving gale-force winds
column4: flooding
column5: heavy rain and possibly snow early in the week of October 28 from an unusual hybrid of Hurricane Sandy and a winter storm producing a Fujiwhara effect. Government weather forecasters said there was a 90% chance that the East Coast would be impacted by the storm. Jim Cisco of the Hydrometeorological Prediction Center coined the term "Frankenstorm"
column6: as Sandy was expected to merge with a storm front a few days before Halloween. As coverage continued
column7: several media outlets began eschewing this term in favor of "superstorm". Utilities and governments along the East Coast attempted to head off long-term power failures Sandy might cause. Power companies from the Southeast to New England alerted independent contractors to be ready to help repair storm damaged equipment quickly and asked employees to cancel vacations and work longer hours. Researchers from Johns Hopkins University
column8: using a computer model built on power outage data from previous hurricanes
column9: conservatively forecast that 10 million customers along the Eastern Seaboard would lose power from the storm.

column1: The intense flooding caused by Hurricane Sandy proved to be too much for water treatment infrastructure on the East Coast of the United States. When the storm ended
column2: more than two-hundred wastewater treatment plants and over eighty drinking water facilities had been severely damaged. The resulting damage caused more than ten-billion gallons of raw sewage to be released into different water sources. This contamination resulted in the shutting down of several drinking water facilities across many different states. The contamination caused by this incident resulted in the EPA issuing a warning that all individuals should avoid coming into contact with the water in Newark Bay and New York Harbor
column3: due to the increased presence of bacteria that is associated with human waste. Similar warnings were issued for water sources in both the Westchester and Yonkers areas due to similarly high levels of bacteria.

column1: Hurricane Sandy sparked much political commentary. Many scientists said warming oceans and greater atmospheric moisture were intensifying storms while rising sea levels were worsening coastal effects. November 2012 Representative Henry Waxman of California
column2: the top Democrat of the House Energy and Commerce Committee
column3: requested a hearing in the lame duck session on links between climate change and Hurricane Sandy. Some news outlets labeled the storm the October surprise of the 2012 United States Presidential election
column4: while Democrats and Republicans accused each other of politicizing the storm.The storm hit the United States one week before its general United States elections
column5: and affected the presidential campaign
column6: local and state campaigns in storm-damaged areas. New Jersey Governor Chris Christie
column7: one of Mitt Romney's leading supporters
column8: praised President Barack Obama and his reaction to the hurricane
column9: and toured storm-damaged areas of his state with the president. It was reported at the time that Sandy might affect elections in several states
column10: especially by curtailing early voting. The Economist wrote
column11: "the weather is supposed to clear up well ahead of election day
column12: but the impact could be felt in the turnout of early voters." ABC News predicted this might be offset by a tendency to clear roads and restore power more quickly in urban areas. The storm ignited a debate over whether Republican presidential nominee Mitt Romney in 2011 proposed to eliminate the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA). The next day the Romney campaign promised to keep FEMA funded
column13: but did not explain what other parts of the federal budget it would cut to pay for it. Beyond the election
column14: National Defense Magazine said Sandy "might cause a rethinking (in the USA) of how climate change threatens national security".In his news conference on November 14
column17: "we can't attribute any particular weather event to climate change. What we do know is the temperature around the globe is increasing faster than was predicted even 10 years ago. We do know that the Arctic ice cap is melting faster than was predicted even five years ago. We do know that there have been extraordinarily — there have been an extraordinarily large number of severe weather events here in North America
column18: but also around the globe. And I am a firm believer that climate change is real
column19: that it is impacted by human behavior and carbon emissions. And as a consequence
column20: I think we've got an obligation to future generations to do something about it."On January 30
column22: days after the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers released a post-Sandy report examining flood risks for 31
column24: 210 km) of the North Atlantic coast
column25: President Obama issued an executive order directing federal agencies
column26: state and local governments drawing federal funds to adopt stricter building and siting standards to reflect scientific projections that future flooding will be more frequent and intense due to climate change.

column1: Power outages and flooding in the area closed the New York Stock Exchange and other financial markets on both October 29 and 30
column2: a weather-related closure that last happened in 1888. When markets reopened on October 31
column3: investors were relieved that it closed relatively flat that day. A week later
column4: the National Association of Insurance Commissioners Capital Markets Bureau noted a slight uptick in the market (0.8%) and suggested that the negative economic impact of Hurricane Sandy was offset by the expected positive impacts of rebuilding.

column1: The destruction of physical infrastructure as a result of Sandy cost impacted states
column2: including New York and New Jersey
column3: tens of billions of dollars. EQECAT
column4: a risk-modeling company that focuses on catastrophes
column5: approximated that impacted regions lost between $30 billion to $50 billion in economic activity. The economic loss was attributed to the massive power outages
column6: liquid fuel shortages
column7: and a near shutdown of the region's transportation system.

column1: Energy: Roughly 8.5 million customers were impacted due to power outages
column2: including many businesses that were hard pressed to deliver products and services in a timely manner. Breaks in gas lines also caused fires in many locations
column3: prompting explosions and destruction of a large amount of residences. Locating gas and diesel fuel proved difficult immediately after Sandy hit
column4: which harmed transportation access for many people.The impairment of the ability to obtain fuel was due to flooding damage in crucial terminals and harbors in areas of New Jersey bordering the Arthur Kill. The shortage of fuel held up first responders as well as other response and recovery officials. Therefore
column5: portable generators remained unutilized
column6: resulting in long lines at fueling stations while individuals were unable to differentiate between the stations that did not hold power from the gas stations that were operational.

column1: Communications: Telecommunications infrastructure was heavily disrupted
column2: impacting millions of people and thousands of businesses
column3: destabilizing the economy of one of the biggest cities in the world. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) found that roughly 25% of cell towers across 10 states were out of service at the peak of the storm.

column1: Green Infrastructure: Hurricane Sandy's storm surge caused erosion of the beaches and dunes
column2: island breaches
column3: and overwash along the coast of New England down all the way to Florida. Flooding along the coast generated substantial erosion of previous natural infrastructure
column4: flooding of wetland habitats
column5: coastal dune destruction or erosion
column6: decimation of coastal lakes
column7: and novel inlet creation.

column1: Transportation: Throughout the history of the country
column2: the nation had not witnessed a worse disaster for public transit systems
column3: including buses
column4: subway
column5: and commuter rail
column6: than when Sandy struck. The morning after the storm hit
column7: on October 30
column9: more than half of the country's daily public transportation riders were unable to commute due to inoperable service. The New York City subway system was shut down two days prior to the storm due to necessary precautions and remained closed through November 1. During that short amount of time
column10: one of the world's largest financial centers experienced immense traffic jams. Those who were able to arrive at work experienced commutes of several hours. Eight New York City subway tunnels were flooded due to a seawater breach which flowed through the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel
column11: impacting various transportation systems throughout the region.Stormwater Management and Wastewater Treatment Systems: There was a massive failure in wastewater treatment facilities all around the mid-Atlantic coast due to floodwaters
column12: large storm runoff
column13: wind damage
column14: and electricity loss. The region's waterways were hit with billions of gallons of raw and partially treated sewage
column15: adversely affecting the health of the public
column16: as well as ocean habitats and other important resources. There was also a public health concern about the threat of contaminated water filling the pipes and wells that supplied potable water to large parts of the region. Large water utility companies experienced power outages
column17: disrupting their ability to provide safe drinking water. Advisories had to be sent out to many parts of New York and New Jersey for customers to warn them of the potential of their water being contaminated.  The “boil water” advisories were later lifted
column19: when it was proven that none of the water was contaminated or held the potential for any ill effects.Public Medical Facilities and Schools: A variety of New York City hospitals and other medical facilities
column20: including the Bellevue Medical Center and Coney Island hospital
column21: were shut down as a result of flooding from the storm. In many parts of the hospitals
column22: there was considerable damage to research
column24: and electrical equipment which was located on lower floors for ease of access. In New Jersey
column25: medical facilities were also severely affected. In sum
column26: the hospitals in the state reported an estimated $68 million in damage. Hudson County had to force closure due to the extensive damage done by the hurricane. Hurricane Sandy also caused schools to close for about a week on average immediately following the storm. During the period of closure
column27: schools attempted to regain control of electrical operations that were impaired by the aftermath.

column1: Thousands of homeowners were denied their flood insurance claims based upon fraudulent engineers' reports
column2: according to the whistleblowing efforts of Andrew Braum
column3: an engineer who claimed that at least 175 of his more than 180 inspections were doctored. As a result
column4: a class-action racketeering lawsuit has been filed against several insurance companies and their contract engineering firms. As of 2015
column5: the Federal Emergency Management Agency planned to review all flood insurance claims.

column1: New Jersey hospitals saw a spike in births nine months after Sandy
column2: causing some to believe that there was a post-Sandy baby boom. The Monmouth Medical Center saw a 35% jump
column3: and two other hospitals saw 20% increases. An expert stated that post-storm births that year were higher than in past disasters.

column1: Because of the exceptional damage and deaths caused by the storm in many countries
column2: the name "Sandy" was later retired by the World Meteorological Organization
column3: and will never be used again for a North Atlantic hurricane. The name was replaced with "Sara" as a naming candidate for the 2018 Atlantic hurricane season ("Sara" ended up unused in 2018 and will next be a candidate in 2024).

column1: As Hurricane Sandy approached the United States
column2: forecasters and journalists gave it several different unofficial names
column3: at first related to its projected snow content
column4: then to its proximity to Halloween
column5: and eventually to the overall size of the storm. Early nicknames included "Snowicane Sandy" and "Snor'eastercane Sandy". The most popular Halloween-related nickname was "Frankenstorm"
column6: coined by Jim Cisco
column7: a forecaster at the Hydrometeorological Prediction Center. CNN banned the use of the term
column8: saying it trivialized the destruction.The severe and widespread damage the storm caused in the United States
column9: as well as its unusual merger with a frontal system
column10: resulted in the nicknaming of the hurricane "Superstorm Sandy" by the media
column11: public officials
column12: and several organizations
column13: including U.S. government agencies. This persisted as the most common nickname well into 2013. The term was also embraced by climate change proponents as a term for the new type of storms caused by global warming
column14: while other writers used the term but maintained that it was too soon to blame the storm on climate change. Meanwhile
column15: Popular Science called it "an imaginary scare-term that exists exclusively for shock value".
